column1: Saskatoon () is the largest city in the Canadian province of Saskatchewan. It straddles a bend in the South Saskatchewan River in the central region of the province. It is located along the Trans-Canada Yellowhead Highway
column2: and has served as the cultural and economic hub of central Saskatchewan since its founding in 1882 as a Temperance colony.With a 2016 census population of 246
column4: Saskatoon is the largest city in the province
column5: and the 17th largest Census Metropolitan Area in Canada
column6: with a 2016 census population of 295
column7: 095. The City of Saskatoon has estimated its population to be 278
column9: while Statistics Canada has estimated the CMA's population to be 330
column10: 674 as of 2019.Saskatoon is home to the University of Saskatchewan
column11: the Meewasin Valley Authority which protects the South Saskatchewan River and provides for the city's popular riverbank park spaces
column13: a National Historic Site of Canada and UNESCO World Heritage applicant representing 6
column14: 000 years of First Nations history. The Rural Municipality of Corman Park No. 344
column15: the most populous rural municipality in Saskatchewan
column16: surrounds the city and contains many of the developments associated with it

column1: Saskatoon is named after the saskatoon berry which is native to the region
column2: and is itself derived from the Cree misâskwatômina. The city has a significant Indigenous population and several urban Reserves. The city has nine river crossings and is nicknamed "Paris of the Prairies" and "Bridge City".

column1: Historic neighbourhoods of Saskatoon include Nutana and Riversdale
column2: which were separate towns before amalgamating with the town of Saskatoon and incorporating as a city in 1906. Nutana
column3: Riversdale
column4: their historic main streets of Broadway Avenue and 20th Street
column5: as well as the downtown core and other central neighbourhoods are seeing significant reinvestment and redevelopment. Sutherland
column6: the rail town annexed by the city in 1956 that lies beyond the University lands
column7: is now another historic old city.

column1: == Etymology ==
The name Saskatoon (in Cree: sâskwatôn
column2: "Saskatoon" or the locatives: misâskwatôminihk
column3: lit: "at the saskatoon berry"
column4: misâskwatôminiskâhk
column5: "at the place of many saskatoon berries"
column6: mînisihk "at the berry") comes from the Cree inanimate noun misâskwatômina "saskatoon berries"
column7: which refers to the sweet
column8: violet-coloured berry that grows in the area.

column1: City of Saskatoon archivist Jeff O'Brien wrote that the traditional story of the name is that it was due to presence of Saskatoon berries in the area. "There is even an almost certainly apocryphal story to the effect that John Lake
column2: upon being given a handful of these berries and told their name immediately cried “Arise
column3: Saskatoon – Queen of the North!”

column1: However
column2: he wrote
column3: "the truth appears to be somewhat less dramatic. The area was long-known to the local Cree as a good place to stock up on willow wands for arrow shafts. Thus the name of the place was “Sask-kwa-tan” – roughly
column4: “the place where willows are cut.”

column1: == History ==

column2: the Toronto-based Temperance Colonization Society was granted 21 sections of land straddling the South Saskatchewan River
column3: between what is now Warman and Dundurn. The aim of the group was to escape the liquor trade in that city and set up a "dry" community in the Prairie region. The following year settlers
column4: led by John Neilson Lake
column5: arrived on the site of what is now Saskatoon and established the first permanent settlement. The settlers travelled by railway from Ontario to Moose Jaw and then completed the final leg via horse-drawn cart
column6: as the railway had yet to be completed to Saskatoon.

column1: In 1885 the Northwest Rebellion affected the tiny community in a variety of ways. Chief Whitecap and Charles Trottier passed through the present day University campus on their way to join Louis Riel's armed forces at Batoche
column2: Saskatchewan. Following the fighting at the Battle of Fish Creek
column3: and the Battle of Batoche
column4: wounded Canadian soldiers convalesced at the Marr Residence which is today a historic site. A few died in care and were buried in the Pioneer Cemetery near the Exhibition Grounds.

column1: A town charter for the west side of the river was obtained in 1903 (Nutana became a village in that year). In 1906 Saskatoon became a city with a population of 4
column3: which included the communities of Saskatoon
column4: Riversdale and Nutana. In 1955 Montgomery Place and in 1956 the neighbouring town of Sutherland were annexed by the fast-growing City of Saskatoon.

column1: == Geography ==
Saskatoon lies on a long belt of rich
column2: potassic chernozem in middle-southern Saskatchewan and is found in the aspen parkland biome. The lack of surrounding mountainous topography gives the city a relatively flat grid
column3: though the city does sprawl over a few hills and into a few valleys. The lowest point in the city is the river
column4: while the highest point is disputed between the suburb of Sutherland in the east side and the Silverwood-River Heights areas in the city's north end. Saskatoon
column5: on a cross-section from west to east
column6: has a general decline in elevation above sea level heading towards the river
column7: and on the east bank of the river
column8: the terrain is mostly level until outside the city
column9: where it begins to decrease in elevation again.

column1: Saskatoon is divided into east and west sides by the South Saskatchewan River. It is then divided into Suburban Development Areas (SDA) which are composed of neighbourhoods. Street addresses are demarcated into north and south (for avenues aligned in those directions) and similar east and west (for streets aligned in those directions). West of the river the demarcation line for north and south addresses is 22nd Street
column2: while east and west are divided by Idylwyld Drive (north of 20th Street) and Avenue A (south of 20th). On the east side
column3: Lorne Avenue demarcates east and west while Aird Street marks the north/south boundary
column4: except in the Sutherland community where a separate east/west demarcation takes place with Central Avenue as the boundary (there is
column5: however
column6: no separate north/south divide). As a result of the unusual demarcation on the east side
column7: few streets actually carry a "North" or "West" designation.

column1: A second major water feature aside from the river is the Hudson Bay Slough
column2: a remnant of a glacier-formed body of water that at one time dominated the northern end of the city. Industrial development has resulted in most of the slough being drained
column3: however a large remnant has been preserved off Avenue C as part of RCAF Memorial Park
column4: and another portion remains intact within the Hudson Bay Industrial area.

column1: Pike Lake and Blackstrap Provincial Parks are 40 km (25 mi) south of the city. Blackstrap Park is often used for school field trips. Batoche is 90 km (56 mi) north of the city.
=== Climate ===
Saskatoon experiences a cold semi-arid climate (Köppen: BSk) near the humid continental climate  (Dfb)
column2: with typically warm summers and long
column3: cold winters. Climate data from University of Saskatchewan
column4: in the inner city meets semi-arid criteria. This is due to slightly higher average annual temperature and slightly lower average annual precipitation than the Airport
column5: on the city's northwest periphery.

column1: The city has four distinct seasons and is in plant hardiness zone 3b. Saskatoon has a dry climate and sees 340.4 mm (13.40 in) of precipitation per year on average
column2: with the summer being the wettest season. Saskatoon is sunnier than average in Canada as a result
column3: averaging 2
column4: 268 hours of bright sunshine annually. The extreme temperatures are typically accompanied by below average levels of humidity. Thunderstorms are common in the summer months and can be severe with torrential rain
column5: hail
column6: high winds
column7: intense lightning and
column9: tornadoes. The frost-free growing season lasts from 21 May to 15 September
column10: but due to Saskatoon's northerly location
column11: damaging frosts have occurred as late as June 14 and again as early as August. The average daytime high temperature peaks at 25.8 °C (78.4 °F) from July 31 to August 8.The "Blizzard of 2007" was described by many residents as the worst they had seen and paralyzed the city with its low visibility
column12: extreme cold and large volume of snow. Winds rose to over 90 km/h (56 mph) and an estimated 25 cm (9.8 in) of snow fell throughout the day. Many area residents took refuge overnight at area work places

column1: The highest temperature ever recorded in Saskatoon was 41.5 °C (107 °F) on 6 June 1988. The lowest temperature ever recorded was −50.0 °C (−58 °F) on 1 February 1893.
== Demographics ==
The 2016 census listed Saskatoon's population at 246
column3: a 10.6 per cent increase over 2011. A civic estimate at the end of 2016 had Saskatoon's population at 265
column4: 300 and Saskatoon's CMA population as 323
column5: 809.According to the 2006 census
column6: 18% of the population consists of youths under the age of 15
column7: while those over 65 constitute 13% of the population. The median age of Saskatoon residents is 35.5 years of age
column8: four years younger than Canada as a whole.The above land area figure was provided by the City of Saskatoon in January 2006 and takes into account recent annexations up to that point. It does not include the two large annexations of land that occurred in the summer of 2010. These portions of land have been zoned under the provincial land management acts.

column1: In terms of race
column2: according to the 2001 census
column4: 120 or 85.4% of the city's population were white Canadians
column6: 900 or 8.9% were Aboriginals
column7: with less than 5% belonging to other visible minority Canadians such as Han Chinese

column1: Some 78.5% of Saskatoon's inhabitants profess to be Christian
column2: mostly Protestant (40.1%) and Roman Catholic (32.5%). Another 19.6% of Saskatoon's inhabitants do not profess a religious faith at all. Minority faiths include Sikhism
column3: Buddhism (0.7%)
column4: Judaism
column5: Hinduism
column6: and Islam (0.6%).

column1: === First Nations ===
The Saskatoon area was inhabited long before any permanent settlement was established
column2: to which the ongoing archaeological work at Wanuskewin Heritage Park and other locations bears witness. Canada's First Nations population has been increasingly urbanized
column3: and nowhere is that more apparent than in Saskatoon
column4: where the First Nations population increased by 382% from 1981 to 2001; however
column5: a portion of this increase
column6: possibly as much as half
column7: is believed to be due to more people identifying themselves as Aboriginal in the census rather than migration or birth rate. Saskatoon has the second highest percentage of First Nations population among major Canadian cities at nearly 9%
column8: behind Winnipeg at 10%  and Regina close by with 8%; in certain neighbourhoods such as Pleasant Hill
column9: this percentage exceeds 40%. Most First Nations residents are of Cree or Dakota cultural background although to a lesser extent Saulteaux

column1: Saskatoon also has a substantial Métis population and is close to the historically significant Southbranch Settlements to the north
column2: as well as the Prairie Ronde settlement near Dundurn
column3: Saskatchewan.

column1: Saskatoon's Sikh community celebrates the festival of Vaisakhi with a parade held in May.The francophone community is represented by the Fédération des francophones de Saskatoon which organizes many cultural events.
=== Galleries and museums ===
Art museums in Saskatoon include the Remai Modern
column2: located at River Landing

column1: The Saskatchewan Craft Council Gallery is on the main floor of the Saskatchewan Craft Council building in the Broadway Avenue area. It is Saskatchewan's only public exhibition gallery dedicated to fine craft as an art form. Saskatchewan Craft Council Gallery presents seven to eight exhibitions each year. The SCC Fine Craft Boutique
column2: located in the gallery
column3: features the work of over 75 SCC fine craft artists.

column3: tools

column5: and clothing

column1: The Forestry Farm Park and Zoo is a National Historic Site situated in the northeast region of the city. The Forestry Farm was a historic nursery (dating from 1913) responsible for growing many of the trees planted within the prairie provinces. In 1966 the nursery operations were discontinued and part of the region turned into a municipal park. The city zoo is also housed within the park and features over 80 species of animals.Wanuskewin Heritage Park is a National Historic Site situated five km to the north of Saskatoon. It is an Aboriginal archaeological site and features displays
column2: special events
column3: and activities
column4: recent renovations are on hold due to a lack of funds during the renovations.

column1: === Theatres ===
Live theatre is a central
column2: vibrant part of Saskatoon's culture. Saskatoon is host to a number of live theatre venues such as the Persephone Theatre
column3: which is in the Remai Arts Centre at River Landing in downtown Saskatoon
column4: The Refinery and the Saskatchewan Native Theatre Company.

column1: The Broadway Theatre primarily shows arthouse films – while the two-screen Roxy Theatre is an "atmospheric-style" second-run theatre that reopened in 2005 after sitting unused for over a decade. The remainder of the city's theatres are multiplexes. The only movie theatre in the downtown core is the Scotia Bank VIP Theatre; the Capitol 4 shut down on April 3
column2: 2008. The city's other movie theatres are The Landmark Theatre in the new subdivision of Brighton
column3: Rainbow Cinemas (a second-run cinema) and the Centre Cinemas in The Centre mall on the city's east side.

column1: Among the many movie theatres of the past that have come and gone was the Capitol Theatre
column2: which opened in 1929 with a showing of the first talkie to be exhibited in Saskatoon. The Capitol closed in the early 1980s to make way for the Scotia Centre office tower; its name was transferred to the aforementioned Capitol 4 a block away. Saskatoon is home to a large blues/jazz community that frequents many bars and clubs known for their blues- and jazz-related acts
column3: including Amigo's

column8: Capitol and formerly Lydia's. The Canadian rock band The Sheepdogs are from Saskatoon.  Joni Mitchell calls Saskatoon her hometown.  The Deep Dark Woods are from Saskatoon.

column1: === Other attractions ===
One of the city's landmarks is the Delta Bessborough Hotel
column2: known to locals as the Bez. Built by the Canadian National Railway
column3: it was among the last railway hotels to be started before the Great Depression of the 1930s brought their era to a close. Although the building was completed in 1932
column4: it did not open its doors until 1935 due to the Depression. The Bessborough and the Mendel Art Gallery are the only major structures on the river side of Spadina Crescent. One of the most frequently circulated photographs of Saskatoon is of the hotel framed in one of the arches of the Broadway Bridge.

column1: The Meewasin Valley Trail follows the South Saskatchewan River through Saskatoon. Summer activities include cycling
column2: jogging and walking through parks and natural areas. Cross-country skiing is popular during the winter months
column3: along with skating in Kiwanis Memorial Park. Access points are found throughout the city with interpretive signage and washrooms along the route. There are parks throughout the Meewasin Valley
column4: with washrooms
column5: picnic facilities
column6: and lookout points along the river bank. In the winter the Meewasin Skating Rink is open free to the public; it is in Kiwanis Memorial Park beside the Delta Bessborough hotel. The outdoor rink has been open since 1980.

column1: For years
column2: a parcel of land west of the Traffic Bridge
column3: south of 19th Street
column4: and east of Avenue C has been the subject of on-again
column5: off-again redevelopment plans. The site formerly held the Saskatoon Arena
column6: a power plant
column7: a branch of the Royal Canadian Legion
column8: and the head offices of the Saskatoon Public School Division; all these structures have been demolished to make way for redevelopment
column9: with plans for same dating back to the 1980s. The most recent version of the plan called River Landing is ongoing. Calgary developer Lake Placid has proposed a 200 million dollar mega hotel/condo project to be built on the site although Lake Placid had difficulty securing financing and missed an October 30
column11: deadline to submit a 4.5 million dollar payment for the parcel of land which seemingly killed the deal. On November 16
column13: it was revealed by Lake Placid that the financing should be secure within a week. In April 2010
column14: Saskatoon City Council voted in favour of entering new negotiations with Lake Placid over the site.

column1: The Saskatoon Farmers' Market and some commercial sites have also been developed. Future plans separate from Lake Placid include the development of a new art gallery to replace the Mendel Art Gallery by 2014. Other landmarks in the city include the iconic Traffic Bridge (which was demolished in 2016 and is currently being replaced by a new structure evoking the appearance of the original)
column2: the University of Saskatchewan campus
column3: and the large Viterra grain terminal which has dominated the western skyline of the city for decades and is large enough to be visible from Pike Lake Provincial Park 32 km away.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Health care ===
The Saskatchewan Health Authority is responsible for health care delivery in the area. They operate three hospitals within the city boundaries
column2: these include Royal University Hospital
column3: Saskatoon City Hospital
column4: and St. Paul's Hospital (Saskatoon). Royal University Hospital is a teaching and research hospital that operates in partnership with the University of Saskatchewan. The health authority also operates hospitals in smaller neighbouring communities. In addition to hospitals the health authority operates long-term care facilities
column5: clinics and other health care services. Jim Pattison Children's Hospital began construction in 2014 and opened in 2019 under the auspices of what was then the Saskatoon Health Region
column6: since absorbed into the Saskatchewan Health Authority.

column1: === Policing ===

The Saskatoon Police Service is the primary police service for the city of Saskatoon and holds both Municipal and Provincial Jurisdiction. The following services also have jurisdiction in Saskatoon: Corman Park Police Service
column2: Royal Canadian Mounted Police
column3: Canadian National Railway Police Service and the Canadian Pacific Railway Police Service. As of December 31
column5: the SPS had 442 sworn members
column6: 59 Special Constables
column7: and 136 civilian positions.

column5: with 1
column6: 606 violent crimes per 100

column9: total crimes against people went up 1.28% and total crimes against property fell by 11.75%.There were accusations in the early 1990s that the Saskatoon police were engaging in starlight tours
column10: where officers would arrest Aboriginal men and drive them out of the city in the dead of winter to abandon them. The majority of the accusations turned out to be true; however
column11: several starlight tour cases lacked evidence.

column1: === Transportation ===
Saskatoon is on the Yellowhead Highway spur of the Trans-Canada Highway system
column2: also known as Highway 16
column3: which connects Saskatchewan
column4: Manitoba
column5: Alberta
column6: and British Columbia. Highways 5
column15: with Highway 60 terminating just outside the southwestern city limits. The following bridges cross the South Saskatchewan River in Saskatoon (in order from upstream):

column1: Construction of Saskatoon's ring road
column2: Circle Drive
column3: began in the mid-1960s (after first being proposed in 1913)

column1: The Canadian Pacific Railway and the Canadian National Railway have connections to Saskatoon. Both railways operate intermodal facilities and trans-load centres; while Canadian National Railway also operates an automotive transfer facility. Saskatoon is a stop on The Canadian passenger transcontinental rail route operated by Via Rail. The Saskatoon railway station is in the city's west end; it opened in the late 1960s as a replacement for Saskatoon's original main station which was on 1st Avenue downtown—the relocation of the station sparked a major redevelopment of the downtown that included the construction of the Midtown Plaza
column2: TCU Place (originally named the Centennial Auditorium) and other developments. The many provincial transportation connections and geographic location of Saskatoon give it one of its nicknames The Hub City. The Saskatchewan Railway Museum is just outside the city. Recent debates about moving all the railways out of the city are raising questions about a future LRT system
column3: but the city's Mayor says the population is too small.Saskatoon/John G. Diefenbaker International Airport
column4: located in the city's northwest
column5: provides scheduled and charter airline service for the city
column6: and is a significant hub for mining and remote locations in Northern Saskatchewan. Non-stop scheduled destinations include Calgary
column7: Edmonton
column15: and Winnipeg. Seasonal and Charter service is provided to Mexico
column20: Westjet and Purolator Courier all have cargo facilities at the airport. Saskatoon/Corman Air Park is a general aviation airport 15 km southeast of Saskatoon.

column1: Transit services in Saskatoon are provided by Saskatoon Transit. The route system was revamped on July 2

Saskatoon was serviced by Greyhound Canada for inter-provincial bus service between Manitoba and Alberta until Greyhound discontinued service on October 31

column1: == Sports and recreation ==
Ice hockey is one of the most popular sports in Saskatoon and is home to numerous amateur teams such as the Saskatoon Blades of the WHL
column2: who host their games in SaskTel Centre (formerly known as Credit Union Centre and Saskatchewan Place). Saskatoon is also home to amateur teams at the Junior B and Midget AAA levels
column3: as well as several youth teams. Saskatoon was a major league hockey city from 1921 to 1926 when the WCHL/WHL Sheiks/Crescents played. They made it as far as the league semi-finals twice
column4: not far enough to challenge for the Stanley Cup.

column1: The biggest chance for a return of major professional hockey came in 1982. Bill Hunter
column2: a local sports promoter
column3: attempted to purchase the St. Louis Blues of the NHL and move it to Saskatoon
column4: but the move was prevented by the league. This was due to Saskatchewan's and especially Saskatoon's small size in relation to both St. Louis and the other cities in the NHL at the time. However
column5: it did cause the building of the Credit Union Centre
column6: on the city's northern edge. Prior to hosting the 2010 World Junior Hockey tournament
column7: the arena underwent a major expansion which increased seating capacity to approximately 15
column8: 000 and also created several new box suites.

column1: Starting in 2016
column2: the Saskatchewan Rush played in the National Lacrosse League after moving from Edmonton. The Saskatchewan Rush won the league Championship against the Buffalo Bandits that same year.

column1: Canadian football is one of the most successful on field sports in Saskatoon. The University of Saskatchewan Huskies are one of the top University football programs in Canada
column2: with three Vanier Cup national championships and 19 Hardy Trophy Canada West championships. The Huskies have made nine Vanier Cup appearances since 1990
column3: and were the first team from outside of Ontario to host the Vanier Cup
column4: hosting the game in 2006. As well
column5: the Saskatoon Hilltops of the Canadian Junior Football League host their games at Gordie Howe Bowl. The Hilltops have won 19 national junior championships throughout their history.

column1: The University of Saskatchewan Huskies play Canadian Interuniversity Sport league games at the University Campus. Their facilities include 6

column3: 700 seat Rutherford Arena
column4: and the state-of-the-art Physical Activity Complex
column5: opened August 2003 in conjunction with the new College of Kinesiology Building. The Huskies participate in twelve sports at the CIS level and have been most successful in football (Conference champions 18 times/National champions 3 times)
column6: men's volleyball (Conference champions 11 times/National champions 4 times) women's basketball National Champions once and men's and women's Track and Field(Conference champions 37 times/ National champions 12 times). Saskatoon is also currently constructing a new arena to be home of the university hockey team. This complex will consist of two areas and a hard court surface for indoor sports events such as soccer. The area is being constructed on the university campus.

column2: two new sports teams came into being in Saskatoon
column3: the Saskatchewan SWAT of the Rocky Mountain Lacrosse League and the Saskatoon Accelerators in the Canadian Major Indoor Soccer League. The Accelerators play at the Kinsmen/Henk Ruys Soccer Centre
column4: while the SWAT play at the Gordie Howe Kinsmen Arena. There are currently no baseball teams in Saskatoon. In the past there have been various teams including the Saskatoon Yellow Jackets
column5: Saskatoon Riot
column6: Saskatoon Smokin' Guns
column7: Saskatoon Stallions

column1: Motor racing is a popular sport in Saskatoon. Saskatchewan International Raceway has been in operation for over 40 years; SIR is home to 1/4 mile NHRA drag racing and holds racing events from May to September. As well
column2: just north of the city lies Wyant Group Raceway the paved oval track is home to local stock car racing
column3: as well as races for several different Western Canadian series. In 2009
column4: the NASCAR Canadian Tire Series make its inaugural stop at Wyant Group Raceway
column5: Formerly known as Auto Clearing Motor Speedway
column6: signaling a move to a larger profile track in Saskatoon. Marquis Downs at Prairieland Park offers live horse racing from May to October.

column1: The city also is home to a number of sports and recreation centres
column2: including two full size soccer facilities under the control of the non-profit Saskatoon Soccer Centre organization. The Kinsmen/Henk Ruys Soccer Centre is composed of four sport court indoor fields and the SaskTel Sports Centre hosts two full sized outdoor turf fields
column3: one indoor full sized turf field
column4: one indoor half sized turf field
column5: and one sport court field. Lions Skatepark was built in the Riversdale area in 2003. As well Saskatoon is home to several golf courses and various parks which include tennis courts
column6: ball diamonds and soccer pitches for spring
column7: summer and fall use and outdoor rinks for winter use. Blackstrap Ski Hill is also 30 minutes south of the city
column9: has been closed since 2006 due to financial difficulty.

column1: == The Crown in Saskatoon ==
Saskatoon has welcomed members of the Royal Family since 1919. The Queen most recently visited for a gala concert at Credit Union Centre
column2: before a live audience of 12
column3: 000 and television viewers nationwide in 2005. The Queen was presented with the key to the city on the same visit
column4: after touring the Canadian Light Source synchrotron and greeting thousands of well-wishers on a walkabout at the University of Saskatchewan (the Queen traditionally stays at the on-campus residence of the President of the University of Saskatchewan when she visits the city). Sovereigns and consorts who have visited include Edward VIII as Prince of Wales in 1919
column5: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth in 1939
column6: and Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh
column7: as Princess Elizabeth in 1951 and afterwards as Queen in 1959

column1: Other members of the Royal Family who have visited include Princess Margaret
column2: Countess of Snowdon in 1980
column3: the Prince of Wales (Charles) in 2001
column4: the Princess Anne in 1982 and (as Princess Royal) in 2004
column5: the Duke and Duchess of York (Andrew and Sarah) in 1989
column6: and the Prince Edward in 1978. Governors General and Lieutenant Governors also pay regular visits to Saskatoon. Saskatonian Ray Hnatyshyn is credited with popularising his office as Governor General from 1990 to 1995. Saskatchewan Lieutenant Governors Barnhart
column7: Fedoruk
column10: Porteous and Worobetz were all former residents of Saskatoon.

column1: Connections to the crown include the royal namesakes of about one hundred neighbourhoods
column2: parks
column3: streets
column4: schools and other places. These include King George
column5: Queen Elizabeth and Massey Place neighbourhoods
column6: and Victoria
column7: Coronation and Princess Diana parks. It was at one time considered that Saskatoon's Broadway Bridge would be renamed George V Bridge. Landmarks and institutions also have connections and these include the Royal University Hospital
column8: one of four royal designations in Saskatchewan. Grade schools named for royals include Ecole Victoria School
column11: Prince Philip School and Princess Alexandra School.

column1: Existing and historic hotels with royal namesakes include the King George Hotel which has been recently converted to ultra-luxury condominiums
column2: the King Edward Hotel
column3: the Queen's Hotel and the Patricia Hotel. The Hotel Bessborough was named for a Canadian Governor General who visited the landmark under construction in the 1930s. The Queen Elizabeth Power Station is within the city and named after Queen Elizabeth. The Prince of Wales Promenade along the South Saskatchewan River is a focal point on the riverfront trails. In 2002
column4: 378 Saskatoon residents were presented with Canada's Golden Jubilee Medal by vice-regals to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the Queen's accession to the throne.
